name: Vancouver
fun_fact: Fun fact: Vancouver has more sushi restaurants per capita than any city outside of Japan, and the California roll was actually invented here in the 1970s by Japanese chef Hidekazu Tojo - a fusion creation that revolutionized Western sushi.

hero_dishes.name: Salmon Oshi Sushi at Miku
hero_dishes.description: Pressed BC wild sockeye salmon aburi-style (flame-seared) with jalapeÃ±o and Miku's signature sauce. The salmon is torched tableside for a smoky, buttery finish.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Miku pioneered the aburi (flame-seared) sushi technique in Vancouver, creating a signature style that's now copied worldwide. Using BC's legendary wild salmon, they transformed traditional Japanese oshi sushi into a West Coast icon.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Miku (ranked #37 on Canada's 100 Best, waterfront location)

hero_dishes.name: Japadog
hero_dishes.description: Teriyaki hot dog with Japanese mayo, nori seaweed, and teriyaki sauce on a toasted bun.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Started by Japanese couple Noriki and Misa Tamura from a street cart in 2005, Japadog became a cult phenomenon by fusing Japanese flavors with Canadian street food. Now a global brand, it all started on Vancouver's streets.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Japadog (multiple locations, original street carts still operating downtown)

hero_dishes.name: Dungeness Crab at Blue Water Cafe
hero_dishes.description: Fresh BC Dungeness crab served whole or as part of a seafood tower, highlighting the sweet, delicate meat with minimal seasoning.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Vancouver's proximity to the Pacific makes Dungeness crab a local treasure. Blue Water Cafe sources from sustainable BC fisheries, serving only what's in season and caught locally.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Blue Water Cafe (specializes in locally sourced sustainable seafood), Joe Fortes Seafood & Chop House

hero_dishes.name: Modern Indian at Lila
hero_dishes.description: Contemporary Indian cuisine blending techniques from The Acorn's Shira Blustein and Vij's Meeru Dhalwala, featuring dishes that reinvent classics with local BC ingredients.
hero_dishes.origin_story: One of 2024's most exciting openings, Lila represents a new generation of Vancouver Indian cuisine - moving beyond traditional tandoori to embrace innovation while respecting culinary heritage.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lila (finalist for Air Canada's Best New Restaurants 2024)

signature_drinks.name: BC Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Vancouver's craft beer scene features IPAs, pilsners, and experimental brews made with local ingredients like Okanagan hops and BC fruit.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at brewpub patios during Vancouver's (rare) sunny days. Locals favor sessionable beers under 5% ABV that pair with the city's diverse food scene.

signature_drinks.name: Caesars
signature_drinks.description: Canada's national cocktail - vodka, Clamato juice, hot sauce, Worcestershire sauce, rimmed with celery salt and garnished elaborately.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The ultimate brunch drink in Vancouver. Bartenders compete to create the most over-the-top garnishes - whole lobster tails, burger sliders, and seafood towers on the rim.

food_culture_notes: Vancouver's food scene is defined by Pacific Rim fusion - Asian techniques meet Canadian ingredients
Sustainability and local sourcing aren't trends here, they're religion - menus change with seasons and ocean conditions
The city has Canada's largest Chinese population outside Asia, making Richmond's dim sum scene legendary
18 Vancouver restaurants made Canada's 100 Best List in 2024, with Published on Main earning a Michelin star
